    • Method Detail

      • hammingDistance

        public double hammingDistance(Puzzle puzzle)
        The Hamming distance computes the number of tiles out of place. The Zero tile is not taken into consideration so that the fitness function becomes admissible.
        Parameters:
        puzzle - The puzzle of which the fitness value will be computed
        Returns:
        A number between 0 and 1, representing the estimated cost to reach the solved puzzle (normalized).
        See Also:
        Hamming Distance

      • manhattanDistance

        public double manhattanDistance(Puzzle puzzle)
        The Manhattan distance computes the total "square distance" between each tile and its correct place. The Zero tile is not taken into consideration so that the fitness function becomes admissible.
        Parameters:
        puzzle - The puzzle of which the fitness value will be computed
        Returns:
        A number between 0 and 1, representing the estimated cost to reach the solved puzzle (normalized).
        See Also:
        Manhattan Distance

      • geometricSeries

        public double geometricSeries(Puzzle puzzle)
        The Geometric Series of sum(2^-n). This fitness function adds the term 2^-i if the tile i is in its place on the current board. Then returns the 1 minus the sum of all terms of tiles in the right place. Proposed by J. Paul Gibson.
        Parameters:
        puzzle - The puzzle of which the fitness value will be computed
        Returns:
        A number between 0 and 1, representing the estimated cost to reach the solved puzzle (normalized).
        See Also:
        Wolfram-Alpha geometric series

      • aStar

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> aStar(Puzzle puzzle,
                                               java.lang.reflect.Method fitnessFunction)
        A* Search Algorithm. As a search algorithm, it starts from the initial board computing the estimated cost to reach the goal board (solved) and, using a priority queue, creates a tree and explores the more promising branches. Known for being extremely memory-overhead. It outputs the elapsed time and sequence of moves found to solve the puzzle.
        Parameters:
        puzzle - The puzzle to solve
        fitnessFunction - Fitness function used to compute the priority of nodes (states of the puzzle).
        Returns:
        The ordered list of steps to follow for solving the puzzle, in the form of Integer meaning which tile to move (swap with the blank space).
        See Also:
        A* Search Algorithm, The 8-Puzzle

      • idaStar

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> idaStar(Puzzle puzzle,
                                                 java.lang.reflect.Method fitnessFunction)
        IDA* Algorithm. Iterative deepening A* is a memory optimization of the A* algorithm, sacrificing performance. It explores every branch of the tree and cuts it when reaching a threshold. It outputs the elapsed time and sequence of moves found to solve the puzzle.
        Parameters:
        puzzle - The puzzle to solve
        fitnessFunction - Fitness function used to compute the priority of nodes (states of the puzzle).
        Returns:
        The ordered list of steps to follow for solving the puzzle, in the form of Integer meaning which tile to move (swap with the blank space).
        See Also:
        IDA* Algorithm, IDA*
